clinical_study.brief_title: Radiofrquency Ablation Combined With Cytokine-induced Killer Cells for Colorectal Cancer Liver Metastases
clinical_study.official_title: Phase III Study of Radiofrquency Ablation Combined With Cytokine-induced Killer Cells for Colorectal Cancer Liver Metastases

lead_sponsor.agency: The First People's Hospital of Changzhou

clinical_study.source: The First People's Hospital of Changzhou

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether combining of radiofrequency ablation (RFA) and cytokine-induced killer cells (CIK) transfusion can prolong survival of patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases (CRCLM).

detailed_description.textblock: The primary objective is to evaluate whether RFA followed by CIK transfusion can prolong survival of patients with resectable CRCLM.

primary_outcome.description: Recurrence-free survival (RFS) was defined as the time from the date of RFA to the date of recurrence or the date of the last follow-up.

secondary_outcome.description: Adverse events related to RFA and CIK treatments.

arm_group.description: Autologous cytokine-induced killer cells were transfer via venous one week after RFA.

intervention.description: Radiofrequency ablation is performed percutaneously under CT/US guidance.
The patients received autologous cytokine-induced killer cells transfusion one week after RFA treatment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma
- Primary lesions (colorectal cancer) are resected
- Must have undergone prior complete resection of the primary tumor; liver metastases
- Must be resectable or accessible for radiofrequency ablation (Five or less lung metastases measuring 5 cm or smaller).
- Serum bilirubin level of 2.0 mg/dl or less.
- Performance status of 0 or 1.
- Expected survival of 1 year or more.
- Informed consent from the patient.
Exclusion Criteria:
- With extrahepatic metastases
- With other neoplastic disease that is measurable or being treated other than colorectal cancer.
